# Code Editors/IDEs

I mean, you can use a plain-text editor like Notepad, but for optimal development experience, you should use a code editor or IDE. A few of the most popular ones are listed below.

# Neovim

Neovimopen in new window is a fork of Vimopen in new window. It is a terminal-based text editor, and written in C and Lua. You can use it together with LunarVimopen in new window, which is an IDE layer for Neovim.

LunarVim

# Visual Studio Code

My personal favourite, Visual Studio Codeopen in new window is a free, open-source (kinda) code editor/IDE developed by Microsoft. It is written in TypeScript and runs on Electron. It has a lot of extensions, and is very customizable.

I like to use it with Github Copilot ðŸ˜„

# Sublime Text

Sublime Textopen in new window is a lightweight code editor that's not free, but has a unlimited trial period (so I don't really see the difference).

# Good Ol' Vim

Vimopen in new window is a terminal-based text editor, and written in C. It is a very powerful editor, and you can use it together with Vim-Plugopen in new window for plugins.

# Geany

Geanyopen in new window is a free and open-source lightweight code editor with basic IDE features. It looks arguably uglier than all other IDEs and editors listed on this page.

# Atom

Deprecated. Still feel kinda sad about it.

# CLion

CLionopen in new window is an IDE for C/C++ development. It is developed by JetBrains, and paid. It is feature rich, but the downside of that is that it is very resource hungry, and according to a MacOS user, uses more RAM than GTA V running in a VM.
